content.description: On the south face there are 2 routes with fixed gear, this is the left route.  Frictiony holds and edges allow you to romp up this route.  My brother took an interesting rolling fall on this one but the small nuts he had placed held, on a rather large fall.  Be careful.
content.protection: 2 bolts and chains atop for the anchor, 2 bolts protect the upper section. Small to medium gear (#.5 and smaller C4s,  #1 to #0 Master Cams) or smaller nuts.

climbs.name: Raisin Bran
climbs.fa: Conrad Anker, Pokey Amory, Drew Bedford, Jamie Cameron 1986

content.description: Right of the bolted line on the east face, is a finger crack that angles right.  Climb this to the ledge and then angle left on the next crack, finally aiming for the tree at the top.  Don't recall if that tree is still alive, though.
content.protection: I believe I set up a top-rope on the tree at the top, bring slings and some gear.  If lead the bottom protects well with small gear, but the middle and top are tougher.  Use brass nuts.

content.description:
Start about 15 feet to the right of Raisin Bran in front of the tree. Follow up the face to the horizontal crack, passing two bolts. Pass four more bolts while trending to the right, ending up in the recessed area under the roof. Hop up over the roof and pass a bolt while following the right leaning crack. From here you'll see three more bolts going up and then trending left to the anchors. There are plenty of gear placements so just try to ignore the bolts and enjoy the easy climbing.

If you know or are the FA please update name, grade, or anything else you would like to see here.
content.protection: A few small/medium cams is more than plenty. 2 bolt anchor on the top.
content.location: The bolted line right of Raisin Bran.

content.description: Follow bolt line using the crack on the left then trending right following crimps and cracks to the chains.
content.location: Starts in the broken corner to the right of Unknown 5.7.

climbs.name: Mr. Potato Head
climbs.fa: Jake Wayman, Kris Pietryga, and James Garrett, 29 September 2009

content.description:
Somewhat squeezed between Isogram and Alien and a number of other R/X(?) routes, this follows really good and fun jugs and horizontals up the face. Should become popular.

Pitch #1: Left of the arete, climb past 5 bolts to the bolted belay of Alien. 5.9, 15m.
content.protection: QDs for 5 bolts to the bolted belay.
content.location: Start climbing right out of the creek left of the arete.

content.description: A wet beginning during all but the dryest of seasons.  Rockhop past the arete to a finger crack that climbs straight up the south face.  This protects well and whereas it is steep the jams are there.  The face is very polished so just use the crack.  This is a very nice crack.
content.protection: 2 bolts for the anchors and medium gear protects the crack.

content.description: This climbs the dirty crack at the right of the south wall.  Dirty, ugly, and only a couple of decent moves needed.  Not worth it, except as a tick.
content.protection: Small to medium gear protects this crack well. Use the 2 bolt anchor up top.

content.description: It requires about 15-20 feet of climbing to your first small nut and then you get better gear shortly after.  This initial climbing is mostly easy but there is one steep move before gear.  Considering adding a bolt to protect these initial moves. Take gear when you can get it.  the gear is small but I was able to protect it well with nuts and a couple small cams.
content.protection: Small gear nothing bigger that .3/blue metolius.  Small nuts are critical, I used a set of peanuts and offset alloys to protect this climb.
content.location: 6 feet to the left of isogram the thin crack you can see from the ground.

content.description: The right-most line with bolts on the south face.  Another decent climb with good angles and steady climbing.  At the top it angles left to the anchors.
content.protection: 2 bolts and chains atop for the anchor, 2 bolts protect the upper section. Small to medium gear (#.5 and smaller C4s,  #1 to #0 Master Cams) or smaller nuts. Protection is solid and the (slightly) runout sections are mellow.

content.description: The bolted line on the face next to the stream.  Nice thin edging, tough on the fingers, and very runout, but a nice climb.  I have to say that, as it was my first 5.11, albeit a top-rope.
content.protection: 2 bolts for the anchors and 2 draws for the climb.  Very runout. Watch the groundfall.

climbs.name: Alien
climbs.fa: Drew Bedford, Pokey Amory, Jamie Cameron, Conrad Anker 1986

content.description: This climbs the arete that arises out of the water.
content.protection: 2 anchors atop.  I top-roped so no beta on leading.  Not a lot of pro though.
